qas.question: What was the ultimate view of Content ID's performance after a 2009 test?
As of 2010 what is the maximum length of a video a user can upload given the proper authority?
How does one dispute the ruling of Content ID?
What happened to the sites rules in Dec. 2010?

plausible_answers.text: that while the system was "surprisingly resilient" in finding copyright violations in the audio tracks of videos, it was not infallible

qas.question: What did a 2010 independent test find?
What is one of the reasons YouTube's rules were modified in December 2009?
What company ran the 2009 test of Content ID?

context: An independent test in 2009 uploaded multiple versions of the same song to YouTube, and concluded <b4_0>that while the system was "<a0_0>surprisingly resilient<a0_0/>" in finding copyright violations in the audio tracks of videos, it was not infallible<b4_0/>. The use of Content ID to remove material automatically has led to controversy in some cases, as the videos have not been checked by a human for fair use. If a <b6_0>YouTube<b6_0/> user disagrees with a decision by Content ID, it is possible to <a2_0>fill in a form<a2_0/> disputing the decision. YouTube has cited <b5_0>the effectiveness of Content ID<b5_0/> as one of the reasons why the site's rules <a3_0>were modified<a3_0/> in December 2010 to allow some users to upload videos of <a1_0>unlimited<a1_0/> length.
